pages.title: Business Income Ebbs and Flows with the Economy
pages.subtitle: Total Business Income, 1958 to 2011, in Billions of 2013 Dollars
pages.body: Since 1958, total U.S. business income has increased significantly, from just under $500 billion in 1958 to over $2 trillion in 2011 (after adjusting for inflation). However, business income is highly susceptible to the ebb and flow of the economy. While income climbed from $1.2 trillion in 2002 to over $3 trillion in 2005 and 2006, it was halved to $1.5 trillion in 2009. From there, it bounced back slightly, reaching over $2 trillion in 2011.

pages.title: Pass-through Entities Are the Most Dominant Business Type
pages.subtitle: Number of Tax Returns for Corporations and Pass-through Entities, 1958 to 2011
pages.body: Businesses in the United States organize into two dominant forms: corporations and pass-through entities (sole proprietorships, partnerships, and S corporations). In the last 50 years, the number of pass-throughs has grown from about 10 million returns in the late 1950s to over 30 million returns today. The Tax Reform Act of 1986, which lowered top tax rates on individuals from 50 percent to 28 percent, made it much more attractive for businesses to pay taxes as pass-throughs rather than as C corporations.
pages.callout: Owners of pass-through entities pay taxes on their individual tax returns. Thus, the income is "passed through" the business to the shareholders.

pages.title: Pass-throughs Now Earn More Business Income Than Corporations
pages.subtitle: Share of Net Income for Passthroughs and C Corporations, 1958 to 2011, in Billions
pages.body: Much of the growth in business income since 1980 has come from pass-through businesses. Pass-throughs now earn over 60 percent of all business income. In 2011, pass-throughs earned $1.3 trillion in business income compared to around $800 billion earned by corporations.
pages.callout: Corporations saw a huge collapse in their income following the financial market crash, falling from nearly $1.3 trillion in 2007 to $450 billion in 2008.
